RUNO

An online multiplayer clone of the popular card game UNO

RUNO is a browser-based multiplayer online game modeled after the popular card game UNO. I built this project in order to get additional hands-on practice covering the new skills I have developed thus far while working through the Full Stack Web Developer Nanodegree and Front-End Web Developer Nanodegree programs offered by Udacity. Here are some examples of problems that I had to solve to successfully complete this project:

  • Perform all game logic on the server side in Python
  • Transmit game state, in JSON, between server and clients
  • Frequently update and persist game state data
  • Synchronize back-end game state file IO
  • Employ object-oriented JavaScript techniques to manage the client-side representations of game objects
  • Manage many dynamic UI elements with jQuery
  • Implement flash messaging system to keep players updated
  • Create a responsive front-end so the game plays well across a wide variety of devices
  • Utilize CSS transitions to create fluid movements

I thoroughly enjoyed working through the challenges that this project presented. It forced me to tap the many skills I've gathered in my full stack studies as well as my front-end studies. I hope you round up some opponents and give the game a whirl. Enjoy!

Portfolio Site

Project #1 for Udacity's Front-End Web Developer Nanodegree

This project is actually the very page you're on right now. Before setting out to complete this project, I had the pleasure of working through three supporting Udacity courses, each one geared towards planning and building websites using HTML and CSS, with responsiveness in mind. Throughout these courses I learned how to do the following:

  • Structure web pages with HTML
  • Style web pages with CSS
  • Build my own grid system
  • Utilize the Bootstrap framework
  • Take the mobile-first approach
  • Employ the latest responsive image techniques
  • Make use of art direction tactics

I believe through executing this project I have demonstrated my ability to properly implement the above tools in order to create websites that look and behave as well on mobile devices as they do on the desktop.

Arcade Game

Project #3 for Udacity's Front-End Web Developer Nanodegree

The primary goal of this project was to get hands-on practice in architecting an object-oriented JavaScript program. Since games consist of various objects, it's the perfect type of application to demonstrate object-oriented design principles. Also, this project focused on the HTML5 canvas API. The two supporting Udacity courses I completed prior to starting this project are "Object-Oriented JavaScript" and "HTML5 Canvas". By working through these courses I learned how to do the following:

  • Utilize object-oriented design principles and patterns
  • Harness the power of JavaScript closures
  • Draw graphics and text using the HTML5 Canvas API
  • Apply filter effects to ImageData objects
  • Process user input by handling browser events
  • Synchronize to the browser framerate with the requestAnimationFrame API

By completing this game project I believe I have demonstrated my ability to effectively write object-oriented JavaScript software, process and render graphics using the HTML5 canvas API, as well as handle user input events. Check out this live link from your phone, tablet, laptop or desktop system to take the game for a spin!

Tournament Results

Project #2 for Udacity's Full-Stack Web Developer Nanodegree

Prior to starting this project I completed Udacity's "Intro to Relational Databases" course. I have worked with SQL before so the language was not new to me. However, I have never used PostgreSQL up to this point, nor have I accessed a database from Python code. Throughout this course I learned how to do the following:

  • Create the schema for a database
  • Define relationships between tables
  • Interact with databases using Python code
  • Sanitize user input to prevent database attacks
  • Use table joins to create complex queries
  • Utilize SQL views to simplify data retrieval

Completing this project enabled me to solidify my existing SQL knowledge as well as stretch it to new bounds. In my career so far I have written business apps utilizing C# and MySQL, so it was fun to learn how to accomplish similar goals using Python and PostgreSQL.

Item Catalog

Project #3 for Udacity's Full-Stack Web Developer Nanodegree

Prior to starting this project I completed two Udacity full-stack web developer courses: "Full Stack Foundations" and "Authentication and Authorization with OAuth". I thoroughly enjoyed learning how to use the Flask framework as well as SQLAlchemy. The power and flexibility of this stack is immense. Throughout these courses I learned how to do the following:

  • Create a web application using Flask
  • Harness the power of Flask's features
  • Create and interact with databases using SQLAlchemy
  • Utilize Google's OAuth2 API to implement an authentication system
  • Implement an authorization system
  • Build a RESTful web application
  • Implement CRUD (create, read, update, delete) methods
  • Build forms for user input
  • Perform client side and server side input validation
  • Process image file uploads
  • Prevent cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks
  • Use other OAuth providers such as Facebook

I had a blast completing this project. I decided to implement a simple music shop website which allows users to log in and create, edit and delete items. Users log in with their Google account and must be verified by an administrator (me) before they have write access to the site. Once enabled, they can create items and then edit or delete those items. Admin accounts can edit or delete any item on the site. Since I'm also working through Udacity's Front-End Web Developer Nanodegree program I decided to push myself to implement a responsive front-end and give it some polish. Check out this live link from your phone, tablet, laptop and desktop systems to see how the layout responds. After finishing this project I now have the necessary set of skills to dig deeper into the Flask framework and SQLAlchemy module to create more complex web applications.

RichOS

A hobby operating system for the x86 architecture PC

I started this project so I have a playground to exercise my problem solving skills and grow my computer science knowledge. I enjoy writing low-level software like this. There's something exciting about having full control over the machine. Sure, I'm just reinventing the wheel... but I think it's really fun!

This project is in its very early stages at this time. Here are some points of interest:

  • My development environment is Ubuntu 15.04 x86-64
  • NASM, GCC, ld, and objcopy are all required to build the OS
  • Upon successful execution of the build script (build.sh) there will be a flat binary file bin/richos.flp
  • I test RichOS using VMware Player, pointing the virtual floppy drive to bin/richos.flp
  • I also test RichOS on a physical machine by writing bin/richos.flp to a USB flash drive, starting at the first sector, then setting my PC to boot from the USB flash drive in floppy emulation mode
  • The boot code is written in mostly 16-bit x86 assembly with a small portion of 32-bit x86 assembly to do some environment setup after switching the CPU from real mode to protected mode
  • The kernel code is written in C, compiled to 32-bit x86 machine code
  • NASM is used to assemble the boot code and GCC is used to compile the kernel
  • Some code in src/boot/bootsect.asm and src/boot/setup.asm borrows heavily from early Linux boot code, but the rest is original
  • All code in src/kernel/ is original, including my (very incomplete) version of the C standard library

Goals for the near future:

  • Complete the parts of the C standard library that are most useful to the kernel
  • Create basic memory management services
  • Write basic interrupt service routines and populate interrupt descriptor table
  • Create a driver for the keyboard

Goals for the distant future:

  • Create drivers for the floppy disk drive and hard disk drive
  • Engineer a custom file system, or create a driver for an existing one
  • Create memory management system utilizing paged virtual memory
  • Implement an experimental user mode consisting of a JavaScript interpreter as the sole API for applications

RichEmu86

Emulator for the x86 architecture PC written in Python

The goal of this project is to write an x86 architecture PC emulator in Python. I'm currently studying object-oriented programming with Python in Udacity's Full-Stack Web Developer Nanodegree program, so I figured this project would be a great way to mix my love of low-level systems programming with my new love, Python.

This project is currently in its infancy at this point. I hope to make small updates frequently in order to get it to a point where it can run 16-bit "real mode" machine code in the near future.

To create the 80x25 terminal window, RichEmu86 utilizes the library graphics.py. The library was written by John Zelle for use with the book "Python Programming: An Introduction to Computer Science" (Franklin, Beedle & Associates).
